thread.title: Rutgers win vs. Indiana last year a statistical outlier
thread.title_full: Rutgers win vs. Indiana last year a statistical outlier

title: Rutgers win vs. Indiana last year a statistical outlier
text:
Rutgers win vs. Indiana last year a statistical outlier Ryan Dunleavy , @rydunleavy 7:51 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Then-Indiana halfback Tevin Coleman plowed through Rutgers defense for 307 rushing yards last season. (Photo: Jim O'Connor, Jim O'Connor-USA TODAY Sports) 3 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY When its opponent rushes for less than 100 yards, Rutgers is 14-6 in four seasons under coach Kyle Flood and 50-16 since 2000. 
As expected, the odds of winning increase when Rutgers opponents rush for fewer than 50 yards (25-3 since 2000) and decrease when opponents reach 100 or more (11-13 under Flood). 
In that case, last season’s game against Indiana is the ultimate outlier, with Rutgers earning a 22-point victory despite allowing a record-setting 307 rushing yards to halfback Tevin Coleman. 
Coleman won’t be part of the rematch, but Indiana coach Kevin Wilson still has a rushing attack averaging more than 200 yards per game at his disposal in Saturday’s rematch against Rutgers. 
“It’s one of the misnomers sometimes when people think of the spread offense,” Flood said. “They think all spread offenses want to throw it around the way Baylor does. 
"But Coach Wilson has always valued running the ball. I think even in some of his comments this week, he’s spoken to wanting to run the ball more, so I think we’re going to get a good dose of it.” Rutgers BOG athletics committee discussed 
Flood referred to Coleman’s performance — the best individual rushing effort ever during a Rutgers on-campus home game — as “the proverbial red gumball.” In other words, the much-desired but hard-to-get prize. 
Coleman was a 2015 NFL Draft third-round pick of the Atlanta Falcons, who are coached by Flood’s longtime friend Dan Quinn. 
“He certainly got a good recommendation from me, I would tell you that,” Flood said. “He’s a special player and a tough guy to defend, but they’ve got good players there now even though they’re a little banged-up at that position.” 
Indiana halfback Jordan Howard leads the Big Ten with 141.8 rushing yards per game and is second to Ohio State’s Ezekiel Elliott with 709 total rushing yards. The UAB transfer missed last week’s game with an ankle injury and is questionable against Rutgers. 
The idea that Rutgers survived Coleman’s barrage with a 45-23 win led one defensive player to respectfully refer to it as a “quiet 300 yards” in the postgame locker room. A year later, however, defensive end Djwany Mera said the number still resonates loudly with him. Eric LeGrand, 5 years after injury, only takes no from Secret Service 
“It definitely touches your heart a little bit,” Mera said, “so we are going to have to figure out some way to stop it this weekend.” 
Rutgers ranks No. 6 in the Big Ten in rushing defense (118.8 yards per game), but Penn State gashed the defense for 330 rushing yards, with two 100-yard backs. 
“Indiana executes well,” defensive tackle Julian Pinnix-Odrick said. “Running backs don’t run for that kind of yardage by themselves. They have a lot of guys back, and they are very efficient. 
“It was too many yards last year, and we are going to try to hold them under that this year by being very detailed with what we do best.” 
Defensive coordinator Joe Rossi appeared to be more aggressive in his play-calling last week in a 31-24 loss to No. 4 Michigan State. Who are the 5 best players Rutgers still must face? 
“We had an emphasis on physicality in practice,” Pinnix-Odrick said. “We don’t play in baby league. Every week is going to be a battle.” 
Pinnix-Odrick has replaced out-for-the-season Darius Hamilton as a starter but isn’t the only defensive lineman taking on an expanded role. 
Nose tackle Kevin Wilkins has seen increased reps, and true freshman Jon Batkey is playing on third downs. 
“We’re having the opportunity to play more guys,” Flood said. “Overall, as you go through the year, you’re going to need that. And if they do have to take on a bigger role — somebody gets dinged up — they’ll be more prepared to do it. 
“It’s good to see that depth being developed. I’ve always said we’d love to play eight defensive linemen in the game, and I think we’re getting pretty close to doing that.” 
Staff Writer Ryan Dunleavy: rdunleavy@gannettnj.com 3 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.app.com/1LwlZar TOP VIDEOS
